Mass. reports zero new coronavirus deaths for the first time in monthsFor the first time in months, state officials on Tuesday reported no new deaths in Massachusetts due to the deadly coronavirus, an encouraging sign that stands in stark contrast to other states around the country. All four key metrics that the state is monitoring to determine the pace of reopening also fell.
The latest COVID-19 numbers from Massachusetts
Key metrics in Massachusetts

Actual number of COVID-19 cases is 12 times higher than reported, with 50 percent more deaths, says MIT studyThe researchers contend that a swifter response to the pandemic could have prevented one-third of all fatalities.

Mass. reports zero new coronavirus deaths for the first time in monthsFor the first time in months, state officials on Tuesday reported no new deaths in Massachusetts due to the deadly coronavirus, an encouraging sign that stands in stark contrast to other states around the country. All four key metrics that the state is monitoring to determine the pace of reopening also fell.

Black renters face egregious housing discrimination, study showsAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

Boston police once resembled the community. But force has grown whiter as city becomes more diverse  The Boston Police Department has failed to keep up with the shifting demographics of the city. Despite pledges from Mayor Martin J. Walsh to diversify the city’s workforce, the police department has become slightly more white as the city’s population has become less so.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.
A ‘tsunami of evictions’ threatens to strike Boston. A disproportionate number will be Black or Latino

A Black woman was driving in her own neighborhood. A white man followed her and accused her of suspicious behaviorA white man allegedly followed a Black Groveland woman and accused her of suspicious behavior while she was driving in her own neighborhood Monday afternoon, in an incident that the police chief said “deeply disturbed” him.

AnalysisThe five people (not named Trump or Biden) who loom large over the 2020 presidential raceWhen Americans vote for president this fall, they basically face a choice between two men: President Trump and Joe Biden. But there are others who factor into the 2020 campaign's stakes and outcomes.

Boston police once resembled the community. But force has grown whiter as city becomes more diverse  The Boston Police Department has failed to keep up with the shifting demographics of the city. Despite pledges from Mayor Martin J. Walsh to diversify the city’s workforce, the police department has become slightly more white as the city’s population has become less so.

Actual number of COVID-19 cases is 12 times higher than reported, with 50 percent more deaths, says MIT studyThe researchers contend that a swifter response to the pandemic could have prevented one-third of all fatalities.

North Brookfield postpones July Fourth celebration that violated state guidelinesA small Worcester County town that had been gearing up for its “1st annual” July Fourth celebration — in open defiance of a state ban on gatherings and requests to cancel from its own Board of Health — pulled the plug just days before the celebration.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.

A white man followed her and accused her of suspicious behaviorA white man allegedly followed a Black Groveland woman and accused her of suspicious behavior while she was driving in her own neighborhood Monday afternoon, in an incident that the police chief said “deeply disturbed” him.

Boston police once resembled the community. But force has grown whiter as city becomes more diverse  The Boston Police Department has failed to keep up with the shifting demographics of the city. Despite pledges from Mayor Martin J. Walsh to diversify the city’s workforce, the police department has become slightly more white as the city’s population has become less so.

Researchers expected ‘outrageously high’ discrimination against Black renters. What they found was worse than imaginedAn undercover investigation found that Black people were shown fewer apartments and that real estate agents cut off contact when renters gave Black-sounding names like Lakisha, Tyrone, or Kareem. In subtle and overt ways, Black renters experienced discrimination in 71 percent of the cases tested.
